**Focus:** Understanding fundamental characteristics of infectious disease transmission and developing accessible software tools for outbreak analysis.

## The mitey Package {.section-header}

::: {.software-highlight}
### Serial Interval & Reproduction Number Estimation

[**mitey**](https://kylieainslie.github.io/mitey/) is a lightweight R package for estimating key epidemiological parameters from outbreak data.

::: {.software-features}
::: {.software-feature}
**Vink Method**<br>
Serial interval estimation from outbreak data with mixture models
:::

::: {.software-feature}
**Time-Varying R**<br>
Reproduction number estimation tracking transmission over time
:::

::: {.software-feature}
**Robust Fitting**<br>
Multiple restarts & convergence diagnostics for reliable estimates
:::

::: {.software-feature}
**Well Documented**<br>
Vignettes with real-world examples and validation
:::
:::

## Disease Investigations {.section-header}

::: {.disease-card}
### Epidemiology of Scabies

Scabies is a contagious skin disease caused by the *Sarcoptes scabiei* mite, affecting over **400 million people annually** worldwide. Despite its prevalence, fundamental epidemiological characteristics have remained poorly described.

Using data from Dutch sentinel surveillance (2011-2023), we provided:

<ul class="finding-list">
<li>**First published estimates** of the mean serial interval of scabies infection</li>
<li>**Time-varying reproduction numbers** showing increasing transmission in recent years</li>
<li>**Methods applicable** to other neglected tropical diseases</li>
</ul>
:::

::: {.disease-card}
### Mpox Transmission

Following the 2022 mpox outbreak in non-endemic regions, we investigated transmission characteristics using detailed exposure histories from cases in the Netherlands.

<ul class="finding-list">
<li>**Serial interval estimates** from identified transmission pairs</li>
<li>**Evidence of presymptomatic transmission** informing isolation guidance</li>
<li>**Public health recommendations** for contact tracing protocols</li>
</ul>
:::
